column1: Maracay (Spanish pronunciation: [maɾaˈkaj]) is a city in north-central Venezuela
column3: and is the capital and most important city of the state of Aragua. Most of it falls under the jurisdiction of Girardot Municipality. The population of Maracay and its surroundings in the 2011 census was 955
column5: Maracay is known as "Ciudad Jardín" ("Garden City").

column2: 1701 by Bishop Diego de Baños y Sotomayor in the valleys of Tocopio and Tapatapa (what is known today as the central valley of Aragua) in northern Venezuela.

column1: According to the most accepted explanation
column2: it was named after a local indigenous chief
column4: a small tiger. Alternative etymologies cite a local aromatic tree called Mara.

column1: Maracay experienced rapid growth during Juan Vicente Gómez's dictatorship (1908–1935). Gómez saw Maracay as a suitable place to make his residence during his rule
column2: and ordered the construction of an Arc of Triumph
column3: a bull plaza (a near replica of the one in Seville
column11: tourist attraction with very large gardens. The city is home to the Mausoleo de Gómez (Gómez's mausoleum)
column12: where the dictator's remains are stored.

column1: One of the most important cities in Venezuela
column2: Maracay is primarily an industrial and commercial center

column1: The areas around Maracay are agricultural: sugarcane
column3: coffee and cocoa stand out as the main products. There are also cattle-herding and timber-cutting activities. Activity by the Venezuelan Military also adds a great deal to Maracay's economy.

column1: Maracay has good transportation facilities and infrastructure. The city is linked to most other important localities by the Autopista Regional del Centro (Central Regional Highway). It also has good access to Venezuela's small national railway system. The city boasts the national Hidroplane airport
column2: located on the shore of the Lago de Valencia (Lake of Valencia). The city does not have a subway system
column3: but one is in the planning stages.

column1: Maracay has two airports. The Airport Mariscal Sucre (IATA MCY ICAO SVBS) and the military Air Base El Libertador (IATA MYC ICAO SVBL)
Maracay is a city heavily influenced by the military. Maracay is the cradle of Venezuelan aviation
column2: and it is home to the two largest Air Force bases in the country. The Venezuelan F-16 fighter planes are stationed here
column3: as well as the new Sukhoi-30MKEs acquired by the Venezuelan Government.

column1: Other military facilities include the Fourth Armored Division of the Army and the Venezuelan Paratroopers main base and training center.

It is also home to the government-owned ammunition and weapons factory (CAVIM) that produces the Venezuelan version of the FN FAL (Fusil Automatique Leger - Light Automatic Rifle) rifle and the AK-103s; as well as the ammunition for both models.
The mountains on the north side of Maracay
column2: that separate it from the coast
column3: make up the Henri Pittier National Park
column4: named after the Swiss naturalist that studied them. The park is a very lush rainforest
column5: with a great variety of ferns.  Two very winding roads cut through the park over the mountains to the coast. One
column6: beginning at the North-Central part of the city known as Urbanización El Castaño
column7: goes to the beach town of Choroní. The other
column8: beginning at the North-Western part at the city of El Limón
column9: goes to Ocumare de la Costa and the beaches of Cata and Cuyagua.

column1: == Higher educational institutions and cultural venues ==
Maracay houses the Faculty of Veterinarians and Agronomy of the Universidad Central de Venezuela
column2: and an extension of the Universidad de Carabobo.

column1: The main Campus of the UNEFA (a military university open to civilians) is located here. Career choices include
column4: as well as other disciplines such as avionics.

column1: The Museum of Modern Arts "Mario Abreu".
The Patron Saint is Saint Joseph.
The San Sebastian's Walk is a religious catholic event with ecological and sport characteristics
column2: which takes place the 20th of January of each year in the outskirts of the city of Maracay.

column1: The city has no synagogue. However
column2: nine indigenous inhabitants converted to Conservative Judaism in Valencia in 2014 after a three-year study course. In 2016
column3: they were denied the right to emigrate to Israel by the Israeli Ministry of Interior
column4: under the assumption that they failed to "belong to a Jewish community" in Maracay.

column1: Maracay is the home of the local baseball team Tigres de Aragua.
The city's Bullfight arena is the only "Maestranza" (bullfighting school) in the country. At the present day is called "Maestranza Cesar Girón"
